title: Lorewise, who wins in a 1v1: Camille or Ekko

replies.body: Camille wins then Camille wins then Camille wins then Camille wins. Then Ekko wins.

{{sticker:sg-syndra}}

This is the perfect answer. It's impossible to permanently defeat someone who can reset time. Even Sans ultimatly failed so Camille stands no chance.

> [{quoted}](name=FloRaider42,realm=EUW,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=zpEE59ru,comment-id=00000000,timestamp=2018-04-26T21:05:11.633+0000)
>
> {{sticker:sg-syndra}}
> 
> This is the perfect answer. It's impossible to permanently defeat someone who can reset time. Even Sans ultimatly failed so Camille stands no chance.

That's assuming she can't injure/destroy his ability to reset time.  If she can then there's a hard limit of tries he gets to win.
Had to rewatch Seconds. Ekkos time reset is really easy to stop now that I think about it. Guess I remembered that wrong.
That's assuming she even gets the chance to realize what he's doing. Remember, everytime Ekko rewinds, it's like the fight is just beginning for her. She doesn't get to keep her memories.

Reset time is OP but not what I would consider unbeatable. Take Xerath or Aurelion Sol. Nothing Ekko has can touch them and they can instantly vaporize him. 

Currently in lore Camille doesn’t know about Ekko so she has no reason to go for time machine and since time resets it will always be the first time she sees it. Meanwhile death by blade is rarely instantaneous. That means there’s almost always going to be time to try and use the machine. 

The exception is if she literally cuts his head off. But since Camille’s design is insane and her pointy bits are all well below the best zones of attack to get instant kills, that puts her at a disadvantage in trying to quickly close the fight. 

Camille is just not designed around winning this one in the long term.

Death by Blade is not instantaneous, no, but you may remember that Ekko's time-reset does *not* heal his wounds from previous attempts. If he gets gashed, he's going to enter the next fight interation with that gash.

Camille doesn't need to cut of his head, she just needs to slice him up enough to win the fight before it even starts for the nth time

True, but he can make the time dilation variable in lore. He gets cut he just goes back past the whole encounter and goes to seek medical attention. Then he knows what Camille is capable of and she still has 0 knowledge of him. 

Furthermore Ekko in lore can interact with multiple alternate timeline versions of himself and coordinate between them. In theory only 1 of these beings need to ever not get hit by Camille’s, again, ridiculously stupid weapon design.

And I’m sorry she can be the greatest martial artist of all time. She ain’t beating alternate timelines.

> [{quoted}](name=Warlord Dienekes,realm=NA,application-id=6kFXY1kR,discussion-id=zpEE59ru,comment-id=00000000000100000000,timestamp=2018-04-26T23:00:24.448+0000)

See my original reply. Camille sets traps and plans fights days, even weeks in advance. She'd know about Ekko's abilities before she ever engaged, and she has the cunning to lay a trap, the accuracy to end the fight in a single shot, and the tools to defeat Ekko's passive defenses (which are essentially none). One shot to the liver and it's over. Ekko can't create multiple timelines around this fight if he doesn't get to go back a single time.

To approach your final comment from another perspective: I can attempt to lift 2,000 pounds a number of times in a number of different ways, but it will fail every time. Ekko doesn't possess the mind to defeat Camille in a one-on-one battle, because Camille doesn't fight. She hunts. If by some miracle he manages to survive the first encounter... Short of seeking tactical education, he'll never truly overcome her. At best, he'll drive her off to be hunted by her a different way the next time.

And even that's giving him way too much credit in the face of this obstacle. Ekko's abilities are impressive, but he has to be able to use them or he literally has nothing to bring to the fight.

She does not know about the fight now. 

What are the rules here. Does Camille only get to know she’s going to kill the time wizard? Does Ekko get to know he’s hunted?

As of right now, currently. Neither knows the other exists and that’s where I place my fight. Sending two foes in blind. 

If we give them a week to prepare?  Honestly, Ekko is a super genius.  I’d be curious what kind of traps and allies he sets up to deal with her. I think that’s going to be a much closer fight for knife-feet than you give credit for. 

Your scenario is just giving Camille every advantage. You do that, and duh. Of course she’ll win.  A peasant can kill Garen if he stabs him while he’s asleep.

Albert Einstein was a super genius. Put him in command of an army, and that army is doomed. Give him a weapon and pit him against a cunning warrior, and he won't last three seconds. Ekko's genius is scientific, not tactical. Scientific genius only helps a tiny bit when you're talking about combat intelligence.

Remember, the OP asked _lorewise_, who wins? Lorewise, Camille is the hunter and those she fights are the hunted. Lorewise, Ekko is generally the scrappy underdog, not the prepared warrior who keeps his head on a swivel. Lorewise, why would they be fighting to begin with? Most likely, Ekko got on the wrong entrepreneur's bad side, and Camille goes in to deal with him. In such a case, Camille knows she's going to kill the time wizard and Ekko doesn't get to know he's hunted, unless he's suddenly developed an acute foresight for danger that's coming days ahead.

But let's assume it's a stand-up fight. Let's assume they're on equal footing. Camille is a superior fighter. Better training, better equipment, better preparation as a general practice, better instincts, better tactical assessment, peerless precision. In the lore, Ekko takes a lot of hits. Most everyone here who gives him the fight says it only happens after taking several effective losses, then rewinding time to get an unfair edge going into the next round.

I argue that Camille is so superior as a fighter that her first hit is going to end it, even if he sees it coming. If not the first, the second or third. Remember, **Ekko takes a lot of hits**, this is lore-established. If a trained mixed martial artist can hit another trained mixed martial artist with a precision knockout punch in the real world, surely a fictional assassin with insane training, hexabionic augments and a perfect eye for reach and points of impact can land a precision strike on a science whiz with a hextech time-crystal.

If that perfect strike lands to the eye, the liver, the heart, or several other places, Ekko's body overloads with adrenaline and shuts down, and he bleeds unconscious by the time it wears off. This is combat science. Seeing as Ekko has nothing in the way of armor to protect against those blows, I don't see how he wins this fight, even face-to-face.

Curiosity, before we go further.  You ever been in a knife fight?  Or even researched stab wounds at all?

Cuz I've done both.  And you cannot just say "oh a stab here and the guy goes down."  That's not how the human body works.  You'll get people who get knocked unconscious after one punch in the gut, and you'll get people still alive and trucking with a hole in their brain.  People have fought back with their esophagus torn off.  Pressure points to consistently shut down a body are pretty much a myth.  They may work, they may completely fail.  Basically on luck.  What you can do is joint locks which can get your opponent into a position where they can't move, most of the effective ones I know work best with the use of your legs.  Or, you can cut off oxygen to your opponent's brain.  This takes somewhere between 30 seconds to 2 minutes depending on the person.  Again, the human body is variable as hell.

Honestly, adrenaline can take you far.  I didn't even realize I was stabbed until about 15 minutes after my fight ended.

As to your assessment.  Superior training?  Sure.  Superior instincts? Probably.  Superior equipment?  Hell no.  Ekko uses time grenades, a time machine, and again has multiple timeline and cross-dimensional bodies to try this with.  Camille lost her legs and decided to replace them with a weapon that is worse than just using a sword in every conceivable way.  I cannot harp on enough about how stupid her design is from a fighting standpoint.

The main issue I have with this argument is this - there are parts of the body that, when cut, the blood loss will be so rapid that you basically only have minutes to live. For example, virtually any major artery. While Ekko operates in seconds rather than minutes, losing blood that rapidly could very well put his body in a state of shock. Logically, Camille being the precision hunter that she is, she would know where and when to strike in order to ensure death.

As for the topic's question of whether Camille or Ekko would win, the important question to be answered is this - when Ekko uses his Chronobreak, are his injuries healed? Because his trailer and the game have conflicting accounts on this matter. Let's say Camille DOES cut one of Ekko's major arteries:

If we can assume the trailer is correct, Ekko going back in time a few seconds isn't going to do him much good because he's losing blood too fast.

If we can assume the game is correct, and Ekko heals his wounds upon slipping back in time, we can also assume that there is a limit on how often he can use it. As such, he has a better chance against Camille in this scenario, but this is a thing he would have to use at EXACTLY the correct time.

Just my five cents.

I'm also pretty sure he was still in the same time Mundo killed him and Mundo knew he hit Ekko and that he jittered back to life.

That's my argument to Ekko victory.

I always assume that he remembers the pain.  As in, he may not be bleeding, but he can still feel the cut, and he is tired.  He is exhausted because he is laboring through it mentally.  But physically sound...tht's something I assume he'll be. For the most part.

My brother-in-law is a combat instructor for the US Army Rangers. I'm mostly going on his knowledge, to be honest, coupled with a little amateur MMA experience. There are a few points on the body that can be hit with sufficient force to reliably buckle any human, according to him; the liver being one of them that mixed martial arts also teaches as a vulnerable point that can end a fight in an instant.

As far as Camille's legs being worse than using a sword in every conceivable way... Assuming she can use her legs almost as well as most people use their arms, which I'll give her because it's fantasy, there are advantages. For one, legs stay out of your opponent's line of sight more frequently than a sword would. For another, legs provide greater reach than an arm and a sword. Not to mention the fact that she can't be disarmed (hahaha it's funny because they're legs).

Good. Then you should know a vulnerable point can end a fight. But you cannot rely on it to end a fight. Boxers regularly take liver and kidney hits and keep trucking. Right up until you can’t. And from my own martial arts experience we are drilled repeatedly to never assume the enemy will go down when you hit 
them. Always keep going to the next step. 

As to Camille. Out of line of sight is iffy but i’ll give you. Longer reach? No. 

Let’s say Camille is 6’, honestly I think she’s a bit shorter but that’s an easy base line. Going by her body proportions that makes her legs about 4’ because she has messed up proportions. But still that gives us a base number. Her arms reach is about 3’. Now a Renaissance rapier has a blade length of 3’4” on average. Some go as long a story 4’. That is a 6’ reach vs a 4’ reach. 

In addition the angle of attack is smaller since all the vital areas on a persons body is at the top. 

And she could actually use 2 feet to balance. Now she is literally balancing on a single knife point whenever she attacks. That is terrible design.  You need to be able to move or redirect yourself and strike simultaneously. 

And finally, she can’t defend herself from upper attacks. Part of the use of swords is defensive parries and counterattacks which she cannot do because of how weird her weapon is positioned.

Camille is actually over 6 feet tall if you look at her comic. There's a panel where she's walking among a bunch of normal people and she's towering over them. Of course, most of this hight comes from her legs, which indeed have more reach than the average person with a sword.

Additionally, she's been shown to be extremely agile and flexible and I'm pretty sure she can defend her self from upper attacks just fine, though mostly due to her ability to dodge them or cut down their source before an attack is even made.

One thing I think people are forgetting in this fight is Camille is extremely fast, precise and calculated. All she needs to do to end this fight is take a single swing at Ekko's neck and watch his head roll. Once the head's gone, he can't use his time machine... cause he's dead.

I think her legs may be longer than that. They look rather... spindly. Regarding defense, if her leg is raised most of the time, assuming she has fine control over it, she has a degree of defense. Not as much freedom as she'd have with a regular old sword, mind, but it's there.

Regarding the liver shot, the reason boxers sometimes keep going is the gloves. When a boxer goes down from a liver shot, it's because of pure force. When a savate kick, for example, brings you down with a liver shot... That's because you get the toes underneath the ribs and dig directly into the liver. That's far more reliable, albeit tougher to land with the pinpoint accuracy required to actually cause an adrenaline dump. But that's why I give Camille this fight; her precision is second to none. Plus, she's not simply throwing a kick. She's puncturing straight through.

It doesn't matter how tough your body is if the liver is pierced right through. For example, if you're wearing a thick gambeson and someone catches you with the edge of a knife once, you're probably not going to feel it. If the gambeson is punctured with a rapier, however, that's going to do significant damage to what's underneath. A tough exterior means nothing if the attack gets inside it.

To be clear, I'm not saying the liver shot would end the fight. I'm not suggesting Camille would stab him through the liver and then walk away the victor. Merely that the resulting adrenaline dump would shut his nervous system off for 2-4 seconds, which is plenty of time for someone like Camille to finish the job any number of ways. Ekko needs to actively _activate_ his time reversal power, which he can't do if his body isn't responding. The point of the precision strike isn't to knock him out cold, but to keep him from activating his ability. Presuming Ekko would be actively defending his neck or his heart, a liver shot would be a great alternative to a more decisive blow.

Exactly this. Everyone thinks he can only rewind time but he can do much more. Literally his every ability ingame is explained by his lore. his w is a time pause, e is him going into the future a bit where he is already on his target, his q is the time grenade he made in the story and his r is his rewind.
It's actually stated somewhere that he does recover injuries, he just still feels some of the pain because can't rewind neurons firing for some reason, so your argument isn't really correct

Can you find that cannon statement somewhere by any chance? As by his trailer, it definitely seems as though his injuries remain post-rewind. If it were just the pain, it shouldn't persist throughout the fight as we saw with Ekko's arm injury. There'd be nothing causing pain after the rewind and it should fade out, but instead he can be seen cradling and not using it the whole time after it gets crushed.

If you behead someone with a blade, that's pretty instant.
That said, all she's gotta do is remove his hands and/or feet and he can't do shit against her or use his device to reset time. She doesn't even HAVE to kill him at that point, just kind of sit there and let him suffer.
Or hell, if she DOES remove his hands and feet, she can wait a few minutes and then press the button for him, to send him hurtling through time back without hands or feet just so her past self can appreciate her efforts. She'd be sadistic that way, I think.
This is just incorrect. If Camille were to decapitate Ekko in one quick kick like she is perfectly capable of, then Ekko is dead and can no longer use the device to rewind time.

(Personal opinion incoming)
Lorewise, it would depend on the surrounding context.

If Ekko got to upsetting the 'normal' way of things, and Camille decided that he wasn't being a good little cog in the system, then his days are numbered.  He may not even know he's been targeted, but hopefully his Zaun upbringing has given him a healthy dose of reasonable paranoia.  In that case, maybe he doesn't expect Camille, but he expects _someone_.

So we have two characters who are brilliant but very different.  Camille is an Intelligencier - she gathers information, identifies weak-points and leverage points, and then surgically strikes them.  Ekko is a creative genius who excels at identifying solutions where no-one else could (and with resources that no-one else would think to use).

{{champion:245}} 
If Ekko suspected he was a target, he would creatively try to solve that problem.  First, he'd try to protect his parents - Zaun would have taught him that when people fight dirty, they'll go at you sideways.  HOW he'd protect his parents is another question, but it's definitely something he'd need to do.  Maybe he'd sell some inventions to get them a small house somewhere quiet in Piltover.  Maybe he'd 'accidentally' win a vacation for them to somewhere nice in Ionia or a beach in Shurima, until things blow over.  Maybe they'd be gifted some hand-me-down looking new coats that are secretly lined with armor of his own invention, or shock defenses or something.  Maybe he'd fake their deaths - not uncommon in Zaun.
Secondly (that is, if he doesn't think his friends are also in danger - if he does, then he'd try to protect them first too) then he'd be on high alert.  He'd likely trap every location that he visits, and have his Z-Drive on speeddial.  He might, if he was especially scared, set up a way to automatically trigger it while he sleeps - so he gets a full night sleep, but to everyone else, he's always awake.

{{champion:164}} 
If Camille perceived Ekko as a threat to the status quo, she'd research the ever living heck out of him first.  Identifying where he goes, who he's friends and family with, if he has enemies, if he has debts, vices, a moral code - anything that could be a point of leverage.  However!  After all that research, I actually believe that Camille's preferred method would be the direct, surgical, strike.  If there was a way of putting Ekko back in his place (losing his job, or being publicly ridiculed, rebuilding after an accident, or having to support a family member) or If she believes that the death of Ekko would cause even more upheaval (if he became a martyr figure, for example) then I don't think she'd kill him.
If he cannot be 'corrected' without death, and his death wouldn't cause a worse situation, then she'd attack head on.  She'd watch him for days (either herself or more likely her agents) and probably locate and disarm all his traps - making sure they still look operational.  She'd assume that she's missed several traps and prepare accordingly.  Likely she'd attack from above or below - human beings are terrible at predicting threats from those directions.  There'd be a faint whirring sound from the shadows, before one of those razor sharp legs slashed him from shoulder to hipbone, body-slamming him to the ground.

Then it's a 50/50 guess as to whether Ekko is still conscious and has enough operation in his arm, to trigger the Z-Drive.  If he does, he's probably dead anyway - his injuries would mostly persist, and from Camille's point of view, he'd simply collapse in a pool of his own blood, near slashed in half, before she even started to descend.

The only alternative I can imagine is if Ekko used the Z-Drive _constantly_ to check every moment for safety, living every second twice, and that sounds exhausting, and unsustainable.  The equivalent of having to test every breath of air for poison before you breathe it, one by one.

(I suppose if he DID know she was coming for him, and she didn't know he knew, he could probably invent some kind of jamming or disabling device that would attack her mechanical body parts, rendering her helpless (maybe even killing her!) if she got close.  If Camille knew that could happen - I suspect she'd send one of the Ferros agents instead, or hire a sniper.)

If it was a fair fight, like in a boxing ring, Ekko would win.  The Z-Drive is just a win button in that situation.

Fair fight: {{champion:245}} 
Preparation allowed: {{champion:164}} 

Ramble over.
